author: ajsutton
content: I'd also say that there's a ton of tools out there (web3j, web3js and all the other web3* variants etc) that already use the REST-API.  Most people tend to just use those tools rather than the APIs directly.

author: sky.cactus
content: My thinking is that if we want data reads (not writes) to move to GraphQL long term, then we should stop implementing new features (like this one) in JSON-RPC.

author: sky.cactus
content: No need to remove existing features yet, but the carrot we can use is "new features available via GraphQL".

author: sky.cactus
content: Alternatively, we could implement a good API and warn users, "if you care about node performance, you should switch to GraphQL".

author: robocopsgonemad3303
content: Greetings ACD! My name is Justin Florentine, I'm a new protocol engineer on the Besu team. Besu team is tracking the issue here https://github.com/hyperledger/besu/issues/2209#issuecomment-862612482

author: robocopsgonemad3303
content: my question for ACD is how do existing clients treat the notion of "latest" default block number when the state tries may not yet be fully synchronized? I'm under the impression that geth only returns the latest, fully synced block, and I'm inclined to make Besu behave the same way.
